ud1.10:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ud1.10:1.3_0: Now at that time Bāhiya of the Bark Cloth was residing by Suppāraka on the ocean shore, where he was honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And he received robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ud1.10:1.4_0: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
ud1.10:1.5_0: “I am one of those in the world who are perfected or on the path to perfection.”
ud1.10:10.1_0: And when the Buddha had given Bāhiya this brief advice he left.
ud1.10:10.2_0: But soon after the Buddha had left, a cow with a baby calf charged at Bāhiya and took his life.
ud1.10:11.1_0: Then the Buddha wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he departed the city together with several mendicants and saw that Bāhiya had passed away.
ud1.10:11.4_0: Having lifted it onto a cot and carried it, cremate it
ud1.10:11.6_0: Mendicants, one of your spiritual companions has passed away.”
ud1.10:12.1_0: “Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. They did as the Buddha asked, then returned to the Buddha
ud1.10:12.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ud1.10:12.3_0: “Sir, Bāhiya’s corpse has been cremated and a monument built for him.
ud1.10:12.4_0: Where have they been reborn in the next life?”
ud1.10:12.5_0: “Mendicants, Bāhiya was astute. He practiced in line with the teachings, and did not trouble me about the teachings.
ud1.10:12.7_0: Bāhiya of the Bark Cloth has become fully extinguished.”
ud1.10:13.1_0: Knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ud1.10:14.2_0: fire and air find no footing;
ud1.10:14.4_0: nor does the sun shed its light;
ud1.10:15.1_0: And when a sage, a brahmin, finds understanding
ud1.10:15.4_0: from pleasure and pain they are released.”
ud1.10:16.2_0: The first sub-chapter on awakening is finished.
ud1.10:2.1_0: Then a deity who was a former relative of Bāhiya, having compassion and wanting what’s best for him, approached him and read the mind of him.
ud1.10:2.2_0: “Bāhiya, you’re not a perfected one, nor on the path to perfection.
ud1.10:2.3_0: You don’t have the practice by which you might become a perfected one or one on the path to perfection.”
ud1.10:3.1_0: “Then who exactly are those in the world who are perfected or on the path to perfection?”
ud1.10:3.2_0: “In the northern lands there is a city called Sāvatthī.
ud1.10:3.3_0: There that Blessed One is now staying, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
ud1.10:3.4_0: He is a perfected one and teaches the Dhamma for the sake of perfection.”
ud1.10:4.1_0: Impelled by that deity, Bāhiya left Suppāraka right away.
ud1.10:4.2_0: Sojourning no more than a single night in any place, he made his way to Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery in the Jeta Grove at Sāvatthī.
ud1.10:4.3_0: At that time a number of monks were walking mindfully in the open air.
ud1.10:4.4_0: Then the Bāhiya went up to those mendicants and said,
ud1.10:4.5_0: “Sirs, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?
ud1.10:4.6_0: For I want to see him.”
ud1.10:4.7_0: “He has entered an inhabited area for almsfood, Bāhiya.”
ud1.10:5.1_0: Then Bāhiya rushed out of the Jeta Grove and entered Sāvatthī, where he saw the Buddha walking for alms. He was impressive and inspiring, with peaceful faculties and mind, attained to the highest self-control and serenity, like an elephant with tamed, guarded, and controlled faculties.
ud1.10:5.2_1: He bowed down with his head at the Buddha’s feet and said,
ud1.10:5.3_0: “Sir, let the Blessed One teach me the Dhamma! Let the Holy One teach me the Dhamma!
ud1.10:5.4_0: is the Dhamma for my lasting welfare and happiness.”
ud1.10:5.6_0: “It’s the wrong time to enter Bāhiya.
ud1.10:6.1_0: For a second time, Bāhiya said,
ud1.10:6.2_0: “Sir, it’s hard for the Buddha’s life span or floods.
ud1.10:6.3_0: Sir, please teach me the Dhamma
ud1.10:6.4_0: is the Dhamma for my lasting welfare and happiness.”
ud1.10:6.5_0: For a second time, the Buddha said,
ud1.10:6.6_0: “It’s the wrong time to enter Bāhiya.
ud1.10:7.1_0: For a third time, Bāhiya said,
ud1.10:7.2_0: “Sir, it’s hard for the Buddha’s life span or floods.
ud1.10:7.3_0: Sir, please teach me the Dhamma
ud1.10:7.4_0: is the Dhamma for my lasting welfare and happiness.”
ud1.10:8.1_0: “In that case, Bāhiya, you should train like this:
ud1.10:8.2_0: ‘In the seen will be merely the seen; in the heard will be merely the heard; in the thought will be merely the thought; in the known will be merely the known.’
ud1.10:8.5_0: When you’re not ‘by that’, you won’t be ‘in that’.
ud1.10:8.6_0: When you’re not ‘in that’, you won’t be in this world or the world beyond or in between the two.
ud1.10:9.1_0: And when the Buddha was freed in brief, his mind was freed from the corruptions without grasping.
